metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Kotlin If ... Else
Kotlin Conditions and If..Else
Kotlin supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
content.html: Kotlin supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

content.text: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.
content.html: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.

content.text: Kotlin has the following conditionals:
Note: Unlike Java, if..else can be used as a statement or as an expression (to assign a value to a variable) in Kotlin. See an example at the bottom of the page to better understand it.
content.html: Note: Unlike Java, if..else can be used as a statement or as an expression (to assign a value to a variable) in Kotlin. See an example at the bottom of the page to better understand it.

content.text: Kotlin if
Use if to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true .
content.html: Use if to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true.

content.code_html:
if (condition) {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition is true
}

content.text: Note that if is in lowercase letters. Uppercase letters (If or IF) will generate an error.
content.html: Note that if is in lowercase letters. Uppercase letters (If or IF) will generate an error.

content.text: In the example below, we test two values to find out if 20 is greater than 18. If the condition is true , print some text:
content.html: In the example below, we test two values to find out if 20 is greater than 18. If the condition is true, print some text:

content.code_html:
if (20 > 18) {
  println("20 is greater than 18")
}

content.text: We can also test variables:

content.code:
val
x
=

20


val
y
=

18


if

(
x
>
y
)

{


println
(
"x is greater than y"
)


}
content.code_html:
val x = 20
val y = 18
if (x > y) {
  println("x is greater than y")
}

content.text: Example explained

In the example above we use two variables, x and y , to test whether x is greater than y (using the > operator). As x is 20, and y is 18, and we know that 20 is greater than 18, we print to the screen that "x is greater than y".
content.html: In the example above we use two variables, x and y, to test whether x is greater than y (using the > operator). As x is 20, and y is 18, and we know that 20 is greater than 18, we print to the screen that "x is greater than y".

content.text: Kotlin else
Use else to specify a block of code to be executed if the condition is false .
content.html: Use else to specify a block of code to be executed if the condition is false.

content.code_html:
if (condition) {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition is true
} else {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition is false
}

val time = 20
if (time < 18) {
  println("Good day.")
} else {
  println("Good evening.")
}
// Outputs "Good evening."

content.text: Example explained

In the example above, time (20) is greater than 18, so the condition is false , so we move on to the else condition and print to the screen "Good evening". If the time was less than 18, the program would print "Good day".
content.html: In the example above, time (20) is greater than 18, so the condition is false, so we move on to the else condition and print to the screen "Good evening". If the time was less than 18, the program would print "Good day".

content.text: Kotlin else if
Use else if to specify a new condition if the first condition is false .
content.html: Use else if to specify a new condition if the first condition is false.

content.code_html:
if (condition1) {
  // block of code to be executed if condition1 is true
} else if (condition2) {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition1 is false and condition2 is true
} else {
  // block of code to be executed if the condition1 is false and condition2 is false
}

val time = 22
if (time < 10) {
  println("Good morning.")
} else if (time < 20) {
  println("Good day.")
} else {
  println("Good evening.")
}
// Outputs "Good evening."

content.text: Example explained

In the example above, time (22) is greater than 10, so the first condition is false . The next condition, in the else if statement, is also false , so we move on to the else condition since condition1 and condition2 is both false - and print to the screen "Good evening".
content.html: In the example above, time (22) is greater than 10, so the first condition is false. The next condition, in the else if statement, is also false, so we move on to the else condition since condition1 and condition2 is both false - and print to the screen "Good evening".

content.text: However, if the time was 14, our program would print "Good day."
content.html: However, if the time was 14, our program would print "Good day."

content.text: Kotlin If..Else Expressions
In Kotlin, you can also use if..else statements as expressions (assign a value to a variable and return it):
content.html: In Kotlin, you can also use if..else statements as expressions (assign a value to a variable and return it):

content.code:
val
time
=

20


val
greeting
=

if

(
time
<

18
)

{


"Good day."


}

else

{


"Good evening."


}


println
(
greeting
)
content.code_html:
val time = 20
val greeting = if (time < 18) {
  "Good day."
} else {
  "Good evening."
}
println(greeting)

content.text: When using if as an expression, you must also include else (required).
content.html: When using if as an expression, you must also include else (required).

content.text: Note: You can ommit the curly braces {} when if has only one statement:
content.html: Note: You can ommit the curly braces {} when if has only one statement:

content.code:
fun

main
(
)

{


val
time
=

20


val
greeting
=

if

(
time
<

18
)

"Good day."

else

"Good evening."


println
(
greeting
)


}
content.code_html:
fun main() {
  val time = 20
  val greeting = if (time < 18) "Good day." else "Good evening."
  println(greeting)
}

content.text: Tip: This example is similar to the "ternary operator" (short hand if...else) in Java.
content.html: Tip: This example is similar to the "ternary operator" (short hand if...else) in Java.
